subject: physics
title: JEE Main: NLM & Friction (15 Qns)

content.q:
A block of mass $M$ is pulled by a force $F$ on a smooth horizontal surface, causing acceleration $a$. If the force is doubled, the new acceleration is: 
(A) $a/2$ 
(B) $a$ 
(C) $2a$ 
(D) $4a$
content.answer: The correct option is (C). According to Newton's Second Law, $F=Ma$, so $a=F/M$. If the force is doubled to $F'=2F$, the new acceleration is $a' = 2F/M = 2a$.

content.q: The linear momentum of a body is increased by $100\%$. The percentage increase in its kinetic energy is: (A) $100\%$ (B) $200\%$ (C) $300\%$ (D) $400\%$
content.answer: The correct option is (C). Kinetic Energy ($KE$) is $p^2/(2m)$. If momentum $p$ increases by $100\%$, the new momentum is $p' = 2p$. New KE is $KE' = (2p)^2/(2m) = 4 \cdot KE$. The increase is $KE' - KE = 3 \cdot KE$, which is a $300\%$ increase.

content.q: A body of mass $5 \text{ kg}$ is suspended by a string. The acceleration (in $\text{m/s}^2$) with which the body must move up such that the tension in the string is $60 \text{ N}$ is: ($g=10 \text{ m/s}^2$) (A) $1 \text{ m/s}^2$ (B) $2 \text{ m/s}^2$ (C) $3 \text{ m/s}^2$ (D) $4 \text{ m/s}^2$
content.answer: The correct option is (B). Applying Newton's Second Law vertically: $T - mg = ma$. Substituting values: $60 - (5)(10) = 5a$. $60 - 50 = 5a$. $10 = 5a$, so $a = 2 \text{ m/s}^2$.

content.q: A force $\vec{F} = 6\hat{i} + 8\hat{j}$ (in $\text{N}$) acts on a body of mass $10 \text{ kg}$. The magnitude of the resulting acceleration (in $\text{m/s}^2$) is: (A) $1$ (B) $1.4$ (C) $10$ (D) $100$
content.answer: The correct option is (A). Magnitude of force is $|\vec{F}| = \sqrt{6^2 + 8^2} = \sqrt{36 + 64} = 10 \text{ N}$. Acceleration $a = F/m = 10 \text{ N} / 10 \text{ kg} = 1 \text{ m/s}^2$.

content.q: The limiting friction is: (A) Always greater than dynamic (kinetic) friction. (B) Always less than dynamic friction. (C) Always equal to dynamic friction. (D) Independent of the normal force.
content.answer: The correct option is (A). Limiting (static) friction is the maximum static friction force ($\mu_s N$), which is generally greater than the kinetic/dynamic friction ($\mu_k N$).

content.q: A bullet of mass $20 \text{ g}$ is fired from a gun of mass $2 \text{ kg}$ with a muzzle velocity of $150 \text{ m/s}$. The magnitude of the recoil velocity of the gun (in $\text{m/s}$) is: (A) $1.5$ (B) $3$ (C) $0.5$ (D) $30$
content.answer: The correct option is (A). By Conservation of Momentum: $m_{\text{bullet}} v_{\text{bullet}} + m_{\text{gun}} v_{\text{gun}} = 0$. $(0.02 \text{ kg})(150 \text{ m/s}) + (2 \text{ kg}) v_{\text{gun}} = 0$. $3 + 2 v_{\text{gun}} = 0$. $v_{\text{gun}} = -1.5 \text{ m/s}$. The magnitude is $1.5 \text{ m/s}$.

content.q: A horse exerts a $200 \text{ N}$ force on a carriage at an angle of $30^\circ$ above the horizontal. The magnitude of the horizontal force component (in $\text{N}$) on the carriage is:

A particle of mass $m=2 \text{ kg}$ is subjected to a time-dependent force $F = 4t$ (in $\text{N}$). If the particle starts from rest, what is the speed (in $\text{m/s}$) after $2 \text{ seconds}$? (Enter the value as an integer)

A block of mass $4 \text{ kg}$ rests on a rough horizontal surface. A horizontal force of $20 \text{ N}$ is applied. If the coefficient of static friction $\mu_s = 0.6$, what is the magnitude of the friction force (in $\text{N}$) acting on the block? ($g=10 \text{ m/s}^2$)
A car of mass $1000 \text{ kg}$ moving at $10 \text{ m/s}$ is stopped by a constant braking force of $2000 \text{ N}$. The time taken (in $\text{seconds}$) for the car to stop is:

Three blocks of masses $m_1=1 \text{ kg}$, $m_2=2 \text{ kg}$, and $m_3=3 \text{ kg}$ are connected by light strings and pulled by a force of $12 \text{ N}$ on a frictionless horizontal surface. The acceleration of the system (in $\text{m/s}^2$) is:

Two objects of mass $10 \text{ kg}$ and $6 \text{ kg}$ are connected by a light string that passes over a smooth pulley (Atwood Machine). The tension (in $\text{N}$) in the string is: ($g=10 \text{ m/s}^2$)

A block of mass $2 \text{ kg}$ slides down a rough incline ($\mu_k=0.5$) with an angle $\theta=37^\circ$ ($\sin 37^\circ = 0.6, \cos 37^\circ = 0.8$). The magnitude of the acceleration (in $\text{m/s}^2$) of the block is: ($g=10 \text{ m/s}^2$)

A block is pulled horizontally with a force $F$ that is just enough to make it slide. The coefficient of static friction is $\mu_s=0.8$. If the mass of the block is $5 \text{ kg}$, the minimum force required to move it (in $\text{N}$) is: ($g=10 \text{ m/s}^2$)
If the net external force acting on a body is zero, its velocity must be: (A) Zero (B) Constant (C) Always increasing (D) Perpendicular to its displacement
content.answer: The correct option is (B). According to Newton's First Law (or Second Law, $F_{\text{net}}=0 \implies a=0$), zero net force means zero acceleration. Zero acceleration means the velocity must be constant (which includes the case of being zero).
